ai.summary: Ben Ledi Trail is a demanding 19.1 km hike in the UK that rewards strong climbers with expansive views from the summit. The route involves a steady, steep ascent and rocky, uneven ground, so it is best tackled by experienced hikers who are prepared for changing weather and long, challenging traverses. Plan for several hours, start early, and be ready for a strenuous day.
ai.terrain_summary: The trail combines forest tracks, steep rocky climbs, and exposed ridges. Expect steep ascents, loose scree near the summit, mud after rain, and uneven footing with roots and stones. Navigation is straightforward on clear days, but mist or wind can reduce visibility, so proper gear and caution are essential.
ai.safety_notes: Weather in the UK can change rapidly; bring appropriate clothing and waterproof layers, sturdy boots, and a fully charged phone. Stay on marked paths, carry a map and compass or GPS, and tell someone your route and expected return. Watch for fatigue, wind exposure near the summit, and loose rocks; if conditions worsen or visibility is poor, consider turning back.
recommended_gear: Sturdy hiking boots with good ankle support
Fully charged mobile phone (with offline maps) and power bank
Headlamp or flashlight with spare batteries
Water container or hydration system (2–3 liters)
High-energy snacks (and a small, lightweight meal if needed)
First aid kit with blister care
Gloves and a warm hat for summit winds
ai.best_seasons: Spring to autumn (roughly April–October) typically offer the best balance of daylight and drier conditions. Winter hikes are possible but require advanced mountaineering experience and proper winter gear.
